ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: true understanding of biomechanics
Basic mechanics and applications to physically systems, applications of differential equations.
I learned a lot in this course, mainly in continuum biomechanics.

I learned about continuum mechanics, statistical mechanics, how to differentiate between the two, applications of biomechanics to the field of biomedical engineering, study skills for a course in which the only grades are the exams, and how to dissect a research paper.
I learned how to solve problems of static deformations, fluid dynamics, viscoelasticity, and statistical mechanics.
A lot of useful computational and conceptual topics!

Solid foundation to continuum mechanics with a little bit of statistical mechanics toward the end. Learned to derive the constitutive relationship for an H.I.E. (homogeneous, isotropic, elastic) material and apply it to word problems; use of Navier-Stokes equation to characterize different kinds of fluid flows (Poiseuille, Couette, and plug flow); laminar and turbulent flows; viscoelastic models (Maxwell, Voigt and three-element); derivation of stress-strain relationships for freely jointed chains; basic principles governing thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Also learned that hydrophobic interactions are really important and ought to be your favorite intermolecular force!) Pro tip: he does a lot of complicated (and maybe unnecessary) derivations of these equations, so try not to get too bogged down in the math and just remember the bigger picture: for any kind of material (elastic solid, fluid, viscoelastic) you're always trying to find a relationship between stress and strain. That's literally it. Remember that and things will make sense for you.

I found this class to be the perfect intersection of engineering/physics with biology. I really enjoyed the math and physics concepts in this course and how it could potentially be applied in a biomedical research setting.
I learned about the foundations of biomechanics: continuum mechanics (solids, fluids, viscoelasticity, poroelasticity) and statistical mechanics (thermodynamics and polymers).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: difficult, but professor is very good
There wasnt much posted material (lecture notes) on canvas to help supplement student learning.

Strengths: Taught very well, lectures were always engaging and most of the material was interesting. 

Weaknesses: No resources outside of attending lecture. No notes are available and no textbook to look back on. The supplemental readings are not very helpful.

Strengths are definitely Dr. Murrell's passion for the course! He is so honest and genuinely wants students to do well. Another huge strength are the TFs -- they are always willing to answer questions and provide very useful insight. I think that at times, the lectures were a bit fast-paced. It is understandable to not want to draw out every mathematical step but it would be helpful to post notes related to the math so that we can review on our own. There were oftentimes when final answers did not correspond to the math steps necessary to get to the answer. I also think it is a bit difficult having the course be graded on just 3 exams. If one has a singular bad day on exam day, it may not accurately reflect their abilities. Therefore, a strength was the extra credit offered but the extra credit assignments were probably not always necessary.

This course covered a wide range of useful material applicable to biology. The main weakness was that there wasn't a lot of practice material offered, as the professor never released practice problems outside of the homeworks. We had 4 homeworks before the first exam, 2 before the second, and only 1 before the third. Additionally, many of the practice problems were unrelated to what we were learning in class, so they were not helpful in preparing for the exams.

I enjoyed the lectures! It would be helpful to have access to the professor's slides when it comes to quantitative parts (like formula derivation, etc.) It would also be helpful to have more practice problems for the quantitative aspects.

This is an unpopular view but Professor Murrell has really improved his teaching method over the six or so years since he started teaching this course. He explains the fundamentals very clearly and emphasizes mastery of basic concepts (ex. Hooke's Law as a mathematical statement of the relationship between stress and strain, meaning of homogeneous/isotropic/elastic assumptions about a material) as a way of gaining understanding of the more challenging applications (ex. he explains how deriving the force-strain relationship for a freely-jointed chain takes you all the way back to Hooke's Law for an elastic solid.) He outlines very clearly what kinds of word problems will be asked on exams, most of which he solves step by step in class. Not sure if he will continue this in a future iteration of this course but for us at least there were opportunities for extra credit to boost everyone's scores. As long as you pay attention, ask questions in class and keep up with the optional homeworks, you will do very well. I do think, however, that having only three exams count for the semester grade places a lot of pressure on students to do well on each of them--I don't think I've ever studied so intensely for a single exam in my time at Yale as I have in 353--so I hope that the problem sets/class quizzes will count for at least part of the grade next year. This class is also quite inaccessible in terms of resources (notes and slides are not posted on Canvas, and lectures are not recorded) so you really, really need to attend every single lecture if you want to do well. All you need to know for the course comes straight out of Murrell's handwritten notes, so take notes copiously and diligently, and don't be afraid to ask for clarification if you don't understand something. Best of luck.

I thought the structure of the class was a great strength of the course, there were a lot of concepts that were covered in-depth. I also enjoyed how the exams and homeworks were given, I think it helped really reinforce the concepts.

I would like to receive more organized equation derivations or explanations of the steps leading to it. While some of the derivation steps that were skipped over could be solved, others were of unclear origin/assumptions.

The only three assignments in the class are the three midterms which are not curved even though the averages are in the C to B range. Homework is given, simply not graded, which is something that should change. The opportunity to do extra credit or revise tests could improve student engagement and learning opportunities.

A strength of this course was that the set of concepts which were explored were pretty interesting. Though the different topics felt pretty disjointed at the beginning of the course, by the end of the course it was clear how the topics came together and were connected to each other. 
The major weakness of this course was that there were limited opportunities to get feedback on one's understanding of the lecture content before the exams. There were ungraded Psets, but they were created separately by the TAs, their answer keys were fairly minimal, and they sometimes did not end up reflecting what was emphasized on the exams. Additionally, the exams had quite a bit of time pressure, to the extent that for the short answer questions, it felt more effective to just memorize derivations rather than understand the process, so that you would be able to complete the questions quickly to be able to get to all of the questions in the time allotted.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, it is required for BME majors
Not really if they weren't a BME major.
I would recommend this students to people outside of the major, it was very interesting and with a more quantitative focus, could also apply to many other engineering/mathematics/physics majors.

Yes, but only if you are biomedical engineering major. The topics are complex and may not be interesting to one who is passionate about studying BME. I would highly recommend taking a course with Dr. Murrell, though, as he is a great professor.

I would recommend this class for a student interested in preparing for higher-level biomechanics courses. The class covers some basic skills like working with Hooke's Law and the Navier Stokes equation, but most of the problems are straightforward and pretty much just require derivations that were done in class.

A solid introductory course to biomechanics. Not as poorly taught as in previous years but still challenging in some places. Not a walk in the park so don't take it just for fun. If you're a BME major you need to take this course -- would recommend reaching out to anyone who has taken this in the past if you're looking for advice.
No, the grading of this course was severe especially as it pertained to the three exams and no other assignments
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the intersection of physics and biology.
no. terrible class. prof doesn't answer your questions directly and doesn't want to give example problems when you ask for more. only take this class if you have to.
If you must.
